properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: Fish population data for Alta Lake, October 1975.

properties.TITLE: Lost Lake Stock Assessment 2001 00803LILL
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: Stocked Lake Fishery Performance in the Thompson-Nicola Region Inland Sport Fisheries Development Initiative
properties.AUTHOR: Webb, Stacy & Steve Maricle
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: Lost Lake (WBID 00221LNTH) is located approximately 21 km northwest of Little Fort, at an elevation of 1310 meters.  To access the lake from Kamloops, take Highway 24 west from Little Fort, then turn north on to the Taweel main haul road.  A 2 WD vehicle is adequate. The Taweel main haul road parallels Lost Lake (although the lake is not clearly visible from any point along the road).  There is a 200 meter trail between the road and the lake. Lost Lake is approximately 10 ha in size and a considerable portion of the lake is made up of littoral area.  The water was tested at the time of the survey and the pH was 7.8. Lost Lake was stocked by the province from 1960 to 1962 and then in 1968 and 1969. 4,000 to 10,000 rainbow trout fry were released in the lake on these years. No stocking has occurred since 1969. Lost Lake now has a self-sustaining population of rainbow trout.

properties.TITLE: Soo TSA Inventory Audit
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: This report presents the results of an inventory audit performed within the Soo TSA, which is located in the south-east portion of the Vancouver Forest Region. It extends along the Lillooet River to Harrison Lake and along the Cheakamus River to Howe Sound. It is bounded by Tree Farm Licence (TFL) 38 on the west. It surrounds Garibaldi Provincial Park. The TSA covers approximately 880, 000 hectares and is administered from the Squamish Forest District office in Squamish.
properties.AUTHOR: Resource Inventory Branch, Ministry of Forest
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: The objective of the inventory audit in the Soo TSA was to assess the overall accuracy of the current (1991 to 1993) Ministry of Forests inventory. The mature and immature forest components were tested but time and resources did not permit assessment of the non-forest component. Audit results for the mature component of the inventory for the Soo TSA suggest that the inventory is statistically acceptable, but borderline. Subsequent analysis of post-stratified data shows a better level of acceptability in the operable forested area. Audit results for the immature component of the inventory suggest an acceptable level of accuracy for site index assignment in young stands. However, there appears to be a trend to underestimate site index.

properties.TITLE: Strathcona TSA Inventory Audit
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: This report presents the results of an inventory audit performed within the Strathcona TSA. The TSA is in the Vancouver Forest Region and is administered from the Campbell River Forest District office. The Strathcona TSA covers central Vancouver Island from the south end of Strathcona Provincial Park to the Brooks Peninsula in the north, and also encompasses several of the islands in the Strait of Georgia and portions of the mainland to the east. The TSA comprises approximately 480 000 ha.
properties.AUTHOR: Resource Inventory Branch, Ministry of Forest
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: The objective of the inventory audit in the Strathcona TSA was to assess the overall accuracy of the current Ministry of Forests inventory. The mature, immature, and non-forest components were tested. Audit results for the mature component of the inventory suggest that the inventory is statistically acceptable. Subsequent analysis of post-stratified data also shows the mature volume inventory is also acceptable for the operable forested area. Audit results for the immature component of the inventory generally suggest an acceptable level of accuracy for site index assignment in young stands. However, there appears to be a trend to underestimate site index in these stands. The audit assessment of the non-forest classification in this TSA indicates that it meets provincial standards.

properties.TITLE: Biophysical Inventory and Enhancement Opportunities for Fitzsimmons Creek, Whistler, BC.
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: Sigma Engineering Ltd. was retained by the Resort Municipality of Whistler to undertake an overview fisheries assessment of the Fitzsimmons Creek watershed.  The purpose of the project was to determine the status of the fish population and the habitat condition in the watershed and to identify any enhancement and management initiatives for improving the fisheries.
properties.AUTHOR: SIGMA ENGINEERING LTD.
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: Sigma Engineering Ltd. was retained by the Resort Municipality of Whistler to undertake an overview fisheries assessment of the Fitzsimmons Creek watershed.  The purpose of the project was to determine the status of the fish population and the habitat condition in the watershed and to identify any enhancement and management initiatives for improving the fisheries.  Green Lake and Lost Lake were not included as part of this assessment.  The field survey was conducted between 11 May and 1 October 1998.  The specific objectives were to: determine the presence and distribution of fish in the Fitzsimmons Creek watershed, describe the stream and riparian habitats, ascertain any fish passage constraints, estimate the carrying capacity of the system by species, recommend enhancement and management initiatives for fish.

properties.TITLE: Rainbow Creek (Alta Lake) 00819LILL
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: The purpose of the project was to investigate the possibility of enhancing rainbow trout production in Rainbow Creek, an influent tributary to Alta Lake near Whistler.
properties.AUTHOR: Wightman, J. C.
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION:
The purpose of the project was to investigate the possibility of enhancing rainbow trout production in Rainbow Creek, an influent tributary to Alta Lake near Whistler.

Rainbow Creek appears to be of marginal value as a source of trout recruitment to Alta Lake. The primary limiting factors are short accessible length, shallow gradient and negligible spawning habitat.

Lake area. This area is developing rapidly, due mainly to its excellent recreation potential. Some form of control is required to insure that orderly efficient development occurs. The soil survey information
will act as an input into the planning and zoning decisions for the area.

properties.TITLE: Level 1 Fish Habitat Assessment of Whistler Creek (Highway 99 to Debris Rack)
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: Nelson Environmental Services has been retained by Whistler Mountain Ski Co. to conduct a fish habitat assessment of Whistler Creek, which will guide the proposed stream works. The suggestions are intended to preserve and enhance the fisheries and other aquatic and riparian habitat in the area. The proposed developments include a redevelopment of the Whistler Creek gondola base, construction of several building, parking lots, lift operations and the skiers bridge/debris rack.
properties.AUTHOR: Nelson Environmental Services
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION:
Whistler Mountain Ski Corporation (WMSC) are presently planning for the redevelopment of the Whistler Creek gondola base. The proposal, as developed by Howard/Bingham/Hill Architects, calls for construction of several building, parking lots, and lift operations near Whistler Creek between Highway 99 and the skiers bridge/debris rack approximately 670 m upstream. Further to those designs, LaCas Consultants Inc. are investigating the hydrology of the creek, and are preparing plans for creek entrainment works. - - - - - -
Nelson Environmental Services has been retained by WMSC to conduct a fish habitat assessment of Whistler Creek, which will provide recommendations for the proposed stream works. The recommendations are intended to preserve and enhance the fisheries and other aquatic and riparian habitat provide by Whistler Creek and the adjacent lands.
- - - - - Recommendations: 
To facilitate reconstruction of the Whistler Creek Gondola Base, LaCas Consultants Inc. are
presently preparing a creek entrainment plan. This plan would include the rip rapping requirements and channel profile for Whistler Creek, from the skiers bridge to Highway 99, as well as provision for a stream crossing at London Lane I Creekside Way. It is also proposed to locate a maintenance access route adjacent to Reaches 1,2 and 3 of Whistler Creek upstream of the proposed crossing. As the proposed works are likely to be extensive, and potentially disruptive to the fish population within the creek, included in this report are recommendations for any proposed creek entrainment works.

properties.TITLE: Intrawest Creekside Project Whistler Creek Management Program 1998 Works
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION:
Intrawest are proposing to redevelop the Whistler Creek area, within the Resort
Municipality of Whistler. In general the plans include residential, commercial, retail and hotel
development, as well as improvements to parking near and adjacent to the existing Whistler
Creek Gondola at the base of Whistler Mountain. This report documents the proposed development details, habitat, mitigation of impacts and details of the construction process.
properties.AUTHOR: Nelson Environmental Services
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION:
Intrawest are proposing to redevelop the Whistler Creek area (Creekside), within the Resort
Municipality of Whistler. In general the plans include residential, commercial retail and hotel
development, as well as improvements to parking near and adjacent to the existing Whistler
Creek Gondola at the base of Whistler Mountain. - - - - - -  The area at present consists of a large day-skier parking lot and several ancillary buildings, including Dusty's Den Restaurant, administrative buildings and trailers, and the disused gondola
barn. The site is generally devoid of vegetation, with the exception of several clumps of riparian
vegetation immediately adjacent to Whistler Creek, and of course upslope on the mountain itself,
where it has not been cleared for ski runs. The creek flows out of a steep ravine downstream of a
back-up municipal water intake, beneath the skiers bridge under the Dave Murray Downhill ski
run, parallels the ski run, flows adjacent to the administration building and gondola barn,
through the day skier parking lot to Highway 99, through culverts at Highway 99s to its mouth at
Nita Lake. Nita Lake ultimately discharges to the Squamish River system via Millar Creek and
the Cheakamus River. A more detailed account of baseline conditions found in and adjacent to
Whistler Creek can be found in the report "Environmental Assessment of Whistler Creek" (Nita
lake to RMOW Back-up Water Intake)" (NES, February 6, 1998)


Conclusions: 
After review of the proposed 1998 creek works, Nelson Environmental Services conclude that the loss of habitat can be mitigated under the proposed replanting and channel works scheme. There would be no net loss of instream habitat, and there would be a net gain in riparian habitat as a result of implementing these works.

properties.TITLE: Pre-design Report on Flood and Debris Flow Hazard Mitigation for Whistler Creek
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: This is a proposal for residential, commercial and infrastructure development in the creekside area of Whistler to try to supplement the larger Whistler Village development. It discusses risk management, flood event potential, proposed conceptual design features, a summary and recommendations.
properties.AUTHOR: Kerr Wood Leidel Associates Ltd.; EBA Engineering Consultants Ltd.

properties.TITLE: Whistler Region Fisheries Stewardship Plan
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: This report provides stream and lake descriptions/fish habitat enhancement opportunities, a five year stream enhancement strategy and a public sign strategy for the Whistler region.
properties.AUTHOR: Thomson, A
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION:
The streams and lakes in the Whistler valley once contained thriving populations of rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss), kokanee salmon (Oncorhynchus nerka), and Dolly Varden char (Salvelinus malma). Before Whistler became internationally recognised as a world class resort, fishing lodges on the valley lakes were successful at maintaining an excellent fishery. However, in the ensuing years, the fish resource declined significantly to the point where some species, notably kokanee and Dolly
Varden, are rarely caught. This decline has been documented in numerous studies conducted on the lakes and streams of the lower valley since the late 1960's. There are a number of reasons for the decline: stream channelization and diversion, instream habitat structure removal, culverting of streams, angling, and foreshore development amongst others. In a bid to restore the fish resource to healthier proportions, a partnership was formed between the Resort Municipality of Whistler, the Whistler Rotary Club, and the Whistler Angling Club to address the ongoing issue of fish habitat alteration. The partnership has commissioned two studies in the last year. The first study, conducted by BCIT student Lucyna Krzesinska in 1995 (Krzesinska, 1995b) involved reviewing previous fish related studies for lakes and streams and documenting general conclusions. The "Description" and "Studies" sections of this text appear unedited within this report.  The second study, conducted in 1996 by Alan Thomson, consultant, involved developing a five year fish habitat enhancement strategic plan for the lower elevation streams within the RMOW boundaries. The following report is a synthesis of the two independent studies.  Many of the stream enhancement projects discussed in this report are designed to be implemented by local stewardship groups. Local involvement is critical to ensuring the projects are implemented, monitored and maintained. Most of the fisheries data that remain outstanding can also be collected and compiled by local groups. However, most of the larger enhancement projects require the assistance of professionals familiar with hydrology and fish habitat enhancement to design and oversee the construction aspects. Conceptual drawings for five fish habitat enhancement projects in
Alta, Crabapple, Rainbow, Whistler and Write-off Creeks are included. These drawings are preliminary and will likely differ from final design drawings once the site specific parameters, such as critical flow rates, gradient, substrate stability, bank stability and others are determined. None of the five projects should be implemented without further analysis and detail.  This report is divided into three sections: Stream and lake descriptions, fish habitat enhancement opportunities, five year stream enhancement strategy and public sign strategy. Enhancement opportunities that had been identified in previous fish related studies by members of the Whistler Rotary Club, Whistler Angling Club, Ministry of Environment Lands and Parks (MoELP) and RMOW are discussed throughout the report. Conceptual designs and estimated costs for the higher priority enhancement projects are included. A five year timetable for enhancement projects provides an implementation scheme.

properties.TITLE: Draft: Coastal Watershed Assessment (Level 1 CWAP) Blackcomb Creek Watershed Whistler, B.C.
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION:
The Forest Practices Code of British Columbia (1995) requires that a watershed
assessment be completed for all watersheds with community water supply and fisheries
values, at the joint request of the Ministry of Forests and the Ministry of Environment.  Contact Mike Nelson at Cascade Environmental Resources - mnelson@cascade-environmental.ca
properties.AUTHOR: GeoAlpine Environmental Consulting
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION:
Blackcomb Skiing Enterprises Limited Partnership (Blackcomb) has developed ski
terrain and facilities on Crown Land since 1979. This mountain development has
involved thinning and clear-cutting of forest for ski trails as well as the establishment of a
road network. GeoAlpine Environmental Consulting was retained by Blackcomb to
conduct a reconnaissance assessment of the possible hydrologic implications of ski
terrain and forestry-related development on the portion of Blackcomb Mountain drained
by Blackcomb Creek and Horstman Creek, using the Level 1 Coastal Watershed
Assessment Procedures (CWAP).  It is important to note that Blackcomb Creek, a community water supply with modest
fisheries values, is the primary focus of this CWAP. From the outset of this investigation
it has been understood that CWAP's are normally conducted for watersheds with more
potential for cumulative hydrological impacts than is expected here, given the relatively
low levels of forestry-related disturbance (ie. significantly less than 20% area logged) in
this drainage. However, in the interest of sound land and resource stewardship,
Blackcomb agreed to a request by the multi-agency round table including Mike Younie
(Ministry of Environment) and Norbert Greinacher (Ministry of Forests) that the scope of
this CWAP be expanded to include the more developed Horstman Creek sub-basin.  Blackcomb Creek is an approximately 17 km2 watershed which discharges into
Fitzsimmons Creek at Whistler Village, B.C. The Blackcomb Creek sub-basin
(approximately 11 km2) includes developed ski terrain on Crown Land, golf facilities on
private land, and a significant portion of parkland in Garibaldi Provincial Park, Blackcomb
Glacier Provincial Park, and Lost Lake Municipal Park. The Horstman creek sub-basin is primarily Crown Land which has been extensively developed for
ski terrain, with a small portion of private land developed for golf facilities.

properties.TITLE: Sea To Sky Lakes Water Chemistry Analysis 2005
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: This project conducted field water quality testing at 13 small lake habitats within the Squamish Forest District, to assess suitability as fish habitat.  Five of the lakes were located in teh Squamish area (Alice, Brohm, Browning, Cat, Stump), whereas 8 were located near Whistler (Alpha, Alta, Green, Loggers, Lost, Nita, Showh North and Showh South).
properties.AUTHOR: Juteau, C; Jesson, D.
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: This project conducted field water quality testing at 13 small lake habitats within the Squamish Forest District, to assess suitability as fish habitat.  Five of the lakes were located in teh Squamish area (Alice, Brohm, Browning, Cat, Stump), whereas 8 were located near Whistler (Alpha, Alta, Green, Loggers, Lost, Nita, Showh North and Showh South). This project was part of a larger MoE initiative in 2005 that focused on lakes within Sea to Sky country.  In addition to water chemistry, stock assessments and angler surveys were conducted at select lakes.  The stock assessment and angler survey results are reported in seperate documents.

properties.TITLE: Sea to Sky Lakes Angler Survey 2005-Whistler
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: An angler survey was conducted from the end of May until early September of 2005 in the Whistler Valley at Alpha, Nita, Alta, and Green Lakes.  The study was conducted to determine fish catch rates and to obtain individual angler information.  Information was collected and reported for each individual lake as well as for all four lakes combined.
properties.AUTHOR: Carmichael, D.
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: An angler survey was conducted from the end of May until early September of 2005 in the Whistler Valley at Alpha, Nita, Alta, and Green Lakes.  The study was conducted to determine fish catch rates and to obtain individual angler information.  Information was collected and reported for each individual lake as well as for all four lakes combined.

properties.TITLE: Terrestrial Ecosystem Mapping Soo Landscape Unit
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: Terrestrial Ecosystem Mapping (1: 20000 scale) in the Soo Landscape Unit, located north of Whistler, B.C., a study area covering approximately 62,515 ha. Information provided describes the background of the project, the study area, objectives, methodology, results and quality control associated with the following mapping types: ecosystem.
properties.AUTHOR: Timberline Natural Resource Group Ltd.; Hawker, S.; Moody, R.; Aleksich, K.; Pavan, E.; Zukanovic, N.; Tanskanen, J.; Forsite Forest Management Specialists; Robertson, I.; Andrew Neale Digital Mapping; Neale, A.; Madrone Environmental Services Ltd.; Reid, H.
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: This project was completed in accordance with the B.C. provincial 1998 Resource Inventory Committee (RIC) standards for Terrestrial Ecosystem Mapping - Digital Data Capture. The project files available include the project report, a TEM ecosystem polygon database, a quality assurance report, an expanded legend and a map legend. The study area covers the following TRIM mapsheets 092J014, J015, J016, J017, J024, J025, J026, J027, J034, J035, and J036. It is situated in the Pacific Ranges Ecoregion / Eastern Pacific Ranges (EPR) Ecosection and includes the Southern Dry Submaritime Coastal Western Hemlock Variant (CWHds1), Southern Moist Submaritime Coastal Western Hemlock variant (CWHms1), Leeward Moist Maritime Mountain Hemlock Variant (MHmm2) and the Leeward Moist Martitime Mountain Hemlock Parkland Variant (MHmmp2) biogeoclimatic subzone variants.

properties.TITLE: Data Sheets Twentyone Mile Creek
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: This document contains various data pertaining to Twentyone Mile Creek, and the Whistler Area. It includes a map of Twentyone Mile Creek, a fish dissection data sheet and a document that lists various files and what they contain, about the Whistler Area.
properties.AUTHOR: Unknown

properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: This report is a result of an investigation to determine the practability of using Twentyone Mile Creek as a source of domestic water for the Alta Lake region.
properties.AUTHOR: C.H. Coulson

properties.TITLE: Stream Classification and Fish Inventory for Scotia and Songhees Creeks
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION:
On May 3, 1995 Scotia Creek was sampled using a Smith Root Model 15-A backpack electrofisher. Biophysical data was obtained by max-min thermometer and
Suunto Clinometer. All distances, including fish lengths, were measured using metric measuring tapes. One fish sample was retained and has been sent to the Pacific Biological Station in Nanaimo for electophoresis.
properties.AUTHOR: North Island Biological Consultants

properties.TITLE: Scientific Collection Summary Report Form Lower Mainland Region Scotia Creek
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: This is a scientific collection summary form for Scotia Creek. It contains a permit number, proponent, project supervisor, sampling program summary (including objectives, location and comments), and general information about Scotia Creek. Specifically the summary regards a fish salvage that occurred, capturing 33 rainbow trout, prior to a log dam removal and channel contouring.
properties.AUTHOR: Nelson Environmental Services; Michalski, J.

properties.TITLE: Scientific Collection Permit Summary Report Form Nineteen Mile Creek

Included information is the proponent name, project supervisor, sampling program summary (objectives, location, comments), sampling program results and general information about the creek.
properties.AUTHOR: Nelson Environmental Services; Geo Alpine Environmental Consulting; Nelson, M.; Williamson, D.

properties.TITLE: A Biophysical Assessment of Lost Lake Tributaries with Reference to Fisheries Enhancement Opportunities 00803LILL
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: Lost Lake, a small body of water situated in the Municipality of Whistler, B.C., is being developed as a recreational area with the development of Whistler as a four season resort. Currently, angling pressure in Lost Lake is light with poor success in catching good sized rainbow trout. As pressure is expected to increase with development, enhancement of fish populations may be required.
properties.AUTHOR: Redekopp, J. H.
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION:
Lost Lake, a small body of water situated in the Municipality of Whistler, B.C., is being developed as a recreational area with the development of Whistler as a four season resort. Currently, angling pressure in Lost Lake is light with poor success in catching good sized rainbow trout. As pressure is expected to increase with development, enhancement of fish populations may be required.

On October 19, 1982, regional fisheries technicians accompanied personnel from the Fish Habitat Improvement Section in conducting a biophysical assessment of Blackcomb Creek, adjacent to Lost Lake. The purpose of the study was to evaluate fish habitat and fish populations in the stream, and to recommend methods of increasing fish production to Lost lake.

properties.TITLE: Ungulate Winter Habitat Capability and Suitability Assessment of Ungulate (Deer and Moose) Winter Ranges in the Soo Timber Supply Area
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: BAPID# 4789 FIA# 3014007. This report is a winter habitat capability and suitability assessment for Deer and Moose in the Soo Timber Supply Area. It includes winter habitat classification, an impact summary and an area breakdown of the winter habitat classifications. Management recommendations and descriptions are provided in regard to Retention, Rotation and Functional winter ranges. Operational guidelines for planning are also provided.
properties.AUTHOR: Ecologic Consulting; Leigh-Spencer, S.
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: This report is a winter habitat capability and suitability assessment for Deer and Moose in the Soo Timber Supply Area. It includes winter habitat classification, an impact summary and an area breakdown of the winter habitat classifications. Management recommendations and descriptions are provided in regard to Retention, Rotation and Functional winter ranges. Operational guidelines for planning are also provided.

properties.TITLE:
Water Quality Data Summary for Green Lake, near Whistler Mountain
00765LILL
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: This report is a summary for Green Lake's Water Quality Data. Gren lake is located near the Whistler ski resort area. There is concern that large schale development in the area and residential subdivision within the watershed will affect the water quality of Green Lake.
properties.AUTHOR: C.J.P. McKean, R.N. Nordin
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: The Waste Management Branch gathered data for a number of years, and requested the Aquatic Studies Branch to examine the lake in more detail. The objective was to assess the general limnology and water quality and provide information which could be used to minimize any adverse effects on Green lake. The lake provides summer recreation and is a very attractive feature of area.

properties.TITLE: Lake Survey - Green Lake 00765LILL
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: This report briefly describes Green Lake, mentions some recent studies done, as well as management/access recommendations should be considered. For Green Lake the management objectives are unclear at this time, although creating a larger fishery then the other three valley lakes is discussed.
properties.AUTHOR: Neuman, R.

properties.TITLE: Ungulate Winter Habitat Assessment -- SOO TSA 2005: Ungulate Winter Habitat Capability and Suitability Assessment of Ungulate (Deer and Moose) Winter Ranges in the Soo Timber Supply Area
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: BAPID# 4822 FIA# 6317004: This report contains information regarding black tailed deer and moose habitat as it pertains to harvesting actions in the Soo Timber Supply Area. This includes ungulate winter ranges, general wildlife measures, suggested operational guidelines for planning, harvesting, planting, stand tending, and road building within the range.
properties.AUTHOR: Leigh-Spencer, S.
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: This report contains information regarding black tailed deer and moose habitat as it and they pertain to harvesting actions in the Soo Timber Supply Area. This includes winter ranges, general wildlife measures, suggested operational giudelines for planning, harvesting, planting, stand tending, and road building within the range. Also included in this report is a large appendix of models, as well as calculations.

properties.TITLE: Fish Collection Permit SU09-54120 Blackcomb Creek
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: This project will use passive telemetry tag technology in a mark recapture study design to evaluate the population size, habitat utilization and life history of adult bull trout captured in Green Lake.
properties.AUTHOR: InStream Fisheries Research Inc.
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: The intention of the project was to capture and tag bull trout returning to Blackcomb Creek via Fitzsimmons Creek to spawn. In 2009 a fish fence and trap built for this specific purpose caught only one single fish.  Additional work conducted in 2010 (SU10-63754) allowed us to capture and tag additional fish that were subsequently used in our study.

properties.TITLE: Fish Inventory Fitzsimmons & Blackcomb Creeks-2014; SU14-151501.
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: Fish sampling was conducted on Fitzsimmons Creek and Blackcomb Creek to address fish distribution, habitat use, juvenile and adult abundance.
properties.AUTHOR: Ecofish Research Ltd.
properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: Sampling was conducted on Fitzsimmons Creek and Blackcomb Creek (control stream) to address the following objectives: 1. Determine species assemblage and upstream limits of distribution for fish species in Fitzsimmons Creek; 2. Assess fish periodicity and habitat use by life stage (juvenile, adult and spawning) in the control, downstream, and project (diversion) reaches; 3. Determine juvenile fish densities and abundance within the different reaches of the project stream; 4.Determine adult fish abundance within the project and control reaches.

properties.LONG_DESCRIPTION: Cascade will conduct fish inventory by electrofishing and minnow trapping for abundance estimate purposes in support of the RMOW 's effort to understand the biodiversity of the region.

properties.TITLE: Fish Salvage Fitzsimmons Creek - 2016; SU16-230153f
properties.SHORT_DESCRIPTION: Fish Salvage Fitzsimmons Creek.
properties.AUTHOR: Cascade Environmental Resource Group
